name: usb 64m smart card
description:
usb 64m smart card, features:
  • support for gb/cgb/gba/gbp
  • supports gb/cgb roms (including lsdj)
  • multiple game roms on the same cartridge are allowed
  • connects to pc via mini-b type usb cable
  • software supported on windows xp, vista, and 7 (OS X, linux, and BSD support in alpha development)
  • easily replaceable battery (for sram). no soldering is required
this cartridge comes with a lsdj sticker. important things to consider:
  • game *.sav file is stored in sram. only one *.sav can be stored at the same time
  • no rom is included on the cartridge. if you need a rom on the cartridge when mailed to you, please read the faq section of this website
  • cartridges are also compatible with the transferrer II system
the driver and software for 32bit Windows operating systems can be downloaded here. for 64bit Windows operating systems here is the driver download link. you will also need this program to install the 64bit drivers. you can find the 64bit driver installation guide here. for linux, OS X, and BSD operating systems you may use this software. it is currently alpha software, but is being actively developed! for a review of this product, please read here, here and here. a compatible usb cable for these cartridges may be found here. additional lsdj stickers may be purchased here. if you want lsdj flashed to your cartridge, please read our FAQs about this here. if you indicate you would like lsdj flashed onto the cartridge, it will be held from shipping until you complete the procedure for this stated in the faq section. it will be held for one week maximum, so please follow through with this process asap. if you do not state this, it will be assumed you do not want any software installed on the cartridge and will be shipped blank.

name: silicone buttons
description: these are replacement silicone buttons for the DMG console. the 'full set' includes a dpad, A/B button, and start/select button. the clear parts are semi-translucent. to install, you only need to remove the factory-installed silicone and plastic buttons and replace them with these. to open the case, you may need a tri-wing screwdriver which can be found here or here.

name: RGBbb
description:
RGBbb is a tri-color backlight for the gameboy dmg and pocket consoles.* it allows you to choose between 7 different color choices when you install it in your gameboy, depending on which wires you connect to the power source:
  • red
  • green
  • blue
  • red + green
  • green + blue
  • red + blue
  • red + green + blue
there are two versions of this backlight, variants A and B. the variant A (va) kit includes:
  • one rgb led backlight panel (1.4mm thick)
  • three resistors
  • polarization film
  • diffusion film
the variant B (vb) kit is a single part:
  • one rgb led backlight panel (1.2mm thick)
the variant B kit is much easier to install, however because it is thinner there is a slight decrease in its brightness. the installation procedure differs between the two variants, please make sure you reference the correct version of the installation documentation. installation documentation (powerpoint format):
  • variant A (va)
    • english
    • español
    • português
  • variant B (vb)
    • english
installation documentation (pdf format):
  • variant A (va)
    • english
    • español
    • português
  • variant B (vb)
    • english
if you wish to have independent control over the brightness of each color, check out the RGBva circuit board. if you intend to only use the backlight for a single color (red, green, or blue) please consider purchasing the LEDx3 instead. * variant B (vb) only

name: metal shielding
description:
these are various metal parts used in console casings for shielding or separating one area from another. all parts are professionally die-cut and made of stainless or carbon steel. brief explanations:
  • dmg - this is the metal shield which screws onto the back half of the casing, separating the cartridge (when inserted) from the main circuit board

name: PISSbox
description:
a datathrash project! the Passive Inverter and Signal Summing box (PISSbox) is a tiny device that performs two simple functions: 1. summing (mixing) two mono signals into one mono signal and 2. inverting one of those two mono signals before summing. the purpose of the PISSbox is noise removal. when using a stereo source with panning capabilities, one input is used for the hard-panned program material and the other is noise floor only (no program material). when the switch is in the INVERT position the noise (present in equal amounts on both channels) is cancelled out leaving a clean mono signal. audio examples (AC adapter for power):
  • CGB with invert off
  • CGB with invert on
  • GBAsp with invert off
  • GBAsp with invert on
documentation is available here.

name: custom buttons
description:
these buttons are machine cast (injection molded) and are a very nice quality.  they are available in a variety of colors and styles.  please see the drop-down menu for the currently available styles and color choices.  

the dmg sets contain the d-pad, A/B buttons, power switch and link port cover.  

the pocket sets contain the d-pad, A/B buttons, and power switch.  

the color sets contain the d-pad, A/B buttons, and power switch.  

the nes sets contain a d-pad, A/B buttons, and also a DMG style power switch and link port cover (many of our customers install this type of button in their DMG).

cgb = gameboy color
dmg = dot-matrix gameboy (the classic)
gbp = gameboy pocket
nes = nintendo entertainment system

colors in the pictures are only a representation.  due to your computer screen's settings, they may not exactly match the plastic.  

* = comes with dpad, A/B buttons, and power switch only
** = comes with dpad and A/B buttons only

description:

we sometimes have various ROMs pre-flashed on an included EPROM, the available titles are listed in the drop-down menu.  the cost difference is for the added EPROM.

description:
this replacement case is designed by kitsch-bent and is fully compatible with the other elements of the game boy dmg console. the original electronics and accessories fit perfectly into this case. notable changes to the design include:
  • fine matte finish
  • squared off corner and back sides for additional interior space
  • alternative speaker grill
  • raised select/start/a/b text
  • minimal surface features
  • 5mm power LED hole (appropriate screen protectors may be found here)
  • retains compatibility with dmg/nes buttons, screen protectors, and available after-market modding devices including backlit LCD screens

  • full (the case, matching buttons, clear screen protector, nickel-plated battery contacts, nickel-plated metal shielding)

name: variable clock v0
description:
a thursday customs product! the smallest version in the "Variable Clock" family, measuring about 7/16"(10mm) long x 5/16"(9mm) wide x 1/4"(7mm) thick. this is a variable clock output device. you can manipulate the speed of the Game Boy processor on the fly with a potentiometer. the pitch of the sound will become lower as you slow it down and it will become higher when you speed it up. you can make some incredible sounds with this kit as well as adding a whole new way to play games! "full kit" comes in two versions:
  • option 1: mini rocker switch, mini potentiometer, and knob
  • option 2: sub-mini toggle switch, micro potentiometer, and knob
installation instructions are in the last picture. save the image for higher quality. a printed version comes with every order!

name: hex switch v1

name: el_dmg
description:
this is a kit for adding an electroluminescent (el) backlight to your gameboy original dmg console. kit includes:
  • el panel (~0.3mm thickness)
  • el_dmg pcb
  • polarization film
  • hook-up wire
features:
  • no hotspotting (like LED backlights)
  • low power consumption (5V@65mA)
  • extremely thin, no pressure is placed on the LCD screen after installation
  • easy to install; pcb/backlight uses headers for connections rather than soldering
  • minimal soldering required (for power, 2 places)
installation documentation (powerpoint format):
  • english
  • español
installation documentation (pdf format):
  • english
  • español
there is a slight electric whine heard when using any el technology, including this circuit and backlight panel. the sound is similar to the level of noise produced by the gameboy light (gbl). if this type of noise is troublesome to you, LED backlights produce no electric hum.

name: USB-to-GameBoy power cables
description:
these cables are for powering a DMG Game Boy Original console via standard USB bus power (USB type A connector).  

just plug right into your computer and ditch the batteries!

the DC plug is at a right-angle to decrease the tension on the DC jack and to help prevent slippage during use.

currently available in four lengths (measured in feet).

name: N64 joystick gears
description:
these are replacement gears for the N64 joystick. 

each set includes two gears needed to replace the two in the original part.

the gears are made from polypropylene (PP) for durability.  you may need to remove a slight bit of 'flash' on the parts, which is typical for plastics parts (to ensure a smoother operation).  this is very easily done with a common razor edge, if even required.

name: RGB switches
description:
this kit can be used to control RGB LED kits such as RGBbb, RGBss and Case LEDs. these three push button switches easily mount to the top of a DMG case to turn red, green and blue on/off to make up to 7 colors. this kit includes:
  • RGB switches PCB with 3 push buttons installed
  • 3 black button caps
  • 2 screws
  • 2 spacers
installation guide is in the last picture.

name: custom battery covers
description:
these are custom battery covers for the DMG console. there are two main types offered here, limited-edition and regularly-occurring. simply, the limited edition covers are only offered one time and when they sell out they are gone forever. the regularly occurring covers will have different color batches and they are intended to be a regular feature in this shop. regarding the limited-edition covers:
  • each design is a limited edition and individually numbered. we've reached out to several pixel artists in the community and will do a series of these limited edition battery covers
  • our first limited edition battery cover's artwork was created by KeFF. it is limited to a strict edition of only 200pcs.
  • collect them all!
regarding the regularly occurring covers:
  • our first regular offering is a LOOMIS x kitsch-bent project. its a play on the classic lines in the DMG's case, bringing them to a gradual point (see photo).

name: case LEDs v1
description:
this kit is used for installing RGB LEDs into a DMG case, with breakout solder points for easy control. with this kit you will get two assembled PCBs each with two LEDs (total of 4 LEDs in a kit). the LEDs are 5mm diffused RGB LEDs. you can make up to 7 different colors:
  • red
  • green
  • blue
  • yellow=red+green
  • cyan=green+blue
  • pink=blue+red
  • white=red+blue+green
you can can choose to have one color installed permanently or install 3 switches to turn red, green and blue off individually to choose between these 7 colors on the fly. this kit is 100% compatible with RGBbb and RGBva. installation instructions:
  • the board is preassembled so all you will need is some wire
  • the pins are labeled R, G, B and V
  • solder pin V to the 5v source on your Game Boy
  • depending on your color choice solder R, G and B (or more) to the ground source on your Game Boy
  • if you want to install switches simply wire one side of all three switches together and connect this to ground
  • then solder R, G and B individually to the other pin of the switches
  • check out the pictures for more info on installation

name: variable clock v1
description:
a thursday customs product! this is a variable clock output device using the popular LTC1799 IC. you can manually change the speed of the processor in your game boy on the fly with a potentiometer for really high or low speeds. the pitch of the sound will become lower as you slow it down and it will become higher when you speed it up. you can make some incredible sounds with this kit! there are some very cool features built right into the PCB:
  • high limiter resistor:
    • this will limit how fast it will go. many devices will crash if pushed too far. a 10K SMD resistor is pre-soldered for installation into an original game boy (DMG) or game boy pocket (MGB)
    • it can easily be removed with a razor blade and you may install a different through hole resistor (i've found that a 4.7k resistor typically works great for playing games on a game boy color (CGB) but will cause programs like lsdj to crash)
  • low limiter resistor:
    • with a 250k pot this kit will go so slow and low that the notes will sound like a droning "growl". if you like you can solder a resistor to the through hole "low limiter" pads and this will only allow the kit to go as slow as you like
    • a 200k to 100k resistor is recommended
the assembled v1.1 PCB and components measure approximately 3/8" x 5/8" (10mm x 15mm) wide and 3/32" (2.5mm) thick. installation instructions:
  • check the 2nd and 3rd pictures
  • picture 2 shows how to connect the PCB
  • picture 3 is the back board of a DMG
  • solder:
    • ground to ground
    • 5V to 5V
    • clock output to clock input (you may choose to install an on/off switch in between this line so that you can shut off the variable speed and return to the normal speed of your game boy or other device
    • solder pins 2 and 3 of the potentiometer of your choice (250k-500k with an audio taper is recommended. 500k will be much slower) to the "POT" pins

name: variable clock v2
description:
a thursday customs project! this is a variable clock output device using the popular LTC1799 IC. you can manually change the speed of the processor in your Game Boy on the fly with a potentiometer for really high speeds or really low speeds. the pitch of the sound will become lower as you slow it down and it will become higher when you speed it up. you can make some incredible sounds and noises with this kit! there are some very cool features built right into the PCB:
  • high limiter:
    • this will limit how fast the device will go. many devices will crash if pushed too far. a 10K SMD resistor is pre-soldered for installation into an Original Game Boy(DMG) or Game Boy Pocket(MGB).
    • this resistor can easily be removed with a razor blade and you may install a through hole resistor (I've found that a 4.7K resistor typically works great for playing games on a Game Boy Color (CGB) but will cause programs like LSDj to crash).
  • low limiter:
    • with a 250K or 500K main pot this kit will go so slow and low that the notes will sound like a droning "growl".
    • this kit comes with a 500K trim pot pre-installed. this will allow you to set the low limit before you install it. or you can install the whole panel in the lower right side of an Original Game Boy (DMG) and the low limiter can be accessed through a small hole with a screw driver.
    • check out this video for a demonstration of how this kit works
this PCB and components measure approximately 7/16" x 3/4"(11mm x 19mm) wide by 1/4"(6mm) tall. installation instructions:
  • check the 1st 2 pictures
  • solder:
    • ground to ground
    • 5V to 5V
    • clock output to clock input
  • solder pins 2 and 3 of the potentiometer of your choice (250K-500K with an audio taper is recommended. 500K will be much slower) to the "P3" and "P3" pins as shown in the 1st picture.
  • the easiest way to install the potentiometer is by removing the speaker from your Game Boy, drilling a hole in the face of the case where the speaker was and using a panel mount potentiometer.
  • you can mount this kit in the lower right side of a DMG and drill a small hole for screw driver access to the low limiter. you will need to cut down the tube so the spot where the trim pot is sits right on top of it for more support. hot glue it in place.

name: variable clock v3
description:
a thursday customs project! this is a variable clock output device using the popular LTC1799 IC. you can manually change the speed of the processor in your Game Boy on the fly with the on-board potentiometer for really high speeds or really low speeds. the pitch of the sound will become lower as you slow it down and it will become higher when you speed it up. you can make some incredible sounds and noises with this kit! there are some very cool features built right into the PCB:
  • high limiter:
    • this will limit how fast the device will go. many devices will crash if pushed too far. a 10K SMD resistor is pre-soldered for installation into an Original Game Boy(DMG) or Game Boy Pocket(MGB).
    • this resistor can easily be removed with a razor blade and you may install a through hole resistor (I've found that a 4.7K resistor typically works great for playing games on a Game Boy Color (CGB) but will cause programs like LSDj to crash).
  • adjustable low limiter:
    • this kit comes with a 500K trim pot pre-installed. this will allow you to set the low limit before you install it. or you can install the whole panel in the lower right side of an Original Game Boy (DMG) and the low limiter can be accessed through a small hole with a screw driver.
installation instructions:
  • check the 3rd and 4th pictures
  • solder:
    • ground to ground
    • 5V to 5V
    • clock output to clock input
  • you can mount this kit in the lower right side of a DMG and drill a small hole for screw driver access to the low limiter, and for the potentiometer shaft.

name: hex v1
description:
a thursday customs product! this is a simple break out board for a dual hex inverter IC (included and assembled). this can be used to "bi-vert" your original game boy (dmg) or game boy pocket (mgb). bi-version gives you a much sharper contrast for your backlit lcd. it will however be more difficult to see in full daylight. installation instructions:
  • first, make sure that your backlit lcd is inverted. when you install the hex board your LCD will have a normal color palette in a much sharper contrast
  • cut the two traces shown precisely where the thin red line is in the 2nd photo
  • solder 6 wires at about 2" (50mm) long to each pin on hex board. you may want to color code them with different colored wires so you don't mix up your lines
  • check the 1st 2 pictures
  • solder:
    • ground to ground
    • 5V to 5V
    • in 1 to in 1
    • in 2 to in 2
    • out 1 to out 1
    • out 2 to out 2
  • you may want to use a little hot glue so your wires don't break. wrap the board in electrical tape and tuck it up in the top behind the main pcb
  • that's it!

name: triple pro-sounder
description:
a thursday customs product! this is a simple audio splitter intended for installing multiple pro-sound mods into a Game Boy. it can be fairly difficult to solder multiple wires to one point. you can use this to install up to 3 different pro-sound jacks into your Original Game Boy (DMG). this panel measures approximately 1/2" x 13/16" (13mm x 21mm) wide and is 1/16" (1.6mm) thick. installation instructions:
  • there are four sets of three through-hole solder pads. choose any one of these sets of three and solder wires to the pads (you may want to color code them with 3 different colored wires so you don't mix up your lines).
  • check the 2nd picture. solder G to ground.
  • if you want volume control then solder L and R to Left and Right (post pot).
  • if you do NOT want volume control and a slightly louder signal then solder L and R to Left and Right (pre pot).
  • from here you can can solder a 1/8" jack, a 1/4" jack and RCAs more easily in your DMG!
*this will work with any Game Boy or any other audio device with similar hook ups. you may not be able to fit this panel as well as other jacks into the smaller Game Boy models.

big thanks to circuit-board.de members arcadeTV and micro, and Rolf. pcb files and more info may be found here (in german).

name: everdrive-GG
description:
this is a flash cartridge for the Sega Game Gear hand-held console developed by krikzz. this cartridge features:
  • max supported ROM size of 8mbit (1mbyte)
  • 32kB FRAM for game save files
  • support for Game Gear and SMS games
  • supports standard Sega and Codemasters mappers
  • USB port for homebrew development*
  • OS updates via SD slot or USB port*
  • RAM data can be loaded/saved via SD slot
  • micro-SD cards supported
  • FAT16 supported. max partition size of 2GB
  • flashed game will stay in storage after power is shut off, so there is no need to reflash after each reset or power-off
cartridge comes with the PCB only. you will need to supply the shell from an older game. only minor modifications for the USB and SD ports are required. the software for this cartridge may be found on the manufacturer's website linked to above. * USB port is only on the 'everdrive-gg USB' version * USB operations are controlled by the Game Gear's Z80 CPU, so the cartridge must be connected to the console for USB/PC communication

RoHS compliant.

name: dmg half-speed crystal oscillator
description:
this crystal oscillator will allow the nintendo® game boy® dmg/classic model to run at half-speed, resulting in a lower range of sounds capable of being produced (lowers notes by one octave).  

crystal value is 2.097152 MHz, so half the speed of the factory installed crystal oscillator.  this crystal oscillator is manufactured by fox (a reputable company for oscillators).

the crystal is non-polar, so the leads (legs) can be installed onto the circuit either direction you wish (unlike some capacitors, for example, that are polarized and have + and -- leads).

simply remove the factory-installed crystal oscillator inside the dmg and replace it with one of these.  because of the size of these crystals, they must be placed elsewhere inside the dmg's case (they are too tall to be soldered from where the factory-installed crystal oscillator was removed). a simple solution is to install the crystal with wires connecting it to the pcb, and then you can place it anywhere you like inside the dmg's case.

(product image is a stock photo and not the actual product, although it reflects the size of the crystal being sold)

name: capacitor kits
description:
installation documentation (powerpoint format):
  • DMG
    • english
    • español (pronto)
    • português (em breve)
  • NES (coming soon)
installation documentation (pdf format):
  • DMG
    • english
    • español (pronto)
    • português (em breve)
  • NES (coming soon)
these are kits for replacing the aluminum electrolytic capacitors in video game consoles. aluminum electrolytic capacitors have an average use-period of fifteen years. when they start to wear out and/or leak their capacitance value changes meaning your video game console is not functioning according to the standards to which it was designed. this type of capacitor is polarized (it has a + and a - leg). please be careful when replacing your capacitors not to put the new cap in backwards. each cap is marked which leg is + and - on the plastic wrapping, and the + leg is the longer of the two. the - is the short one. we will be adding more kits for additional consoles when they are ready.

name: easy_CLK
description:
this circuit is a replacement for the crystal oscillator inside the DMG console (although it is adaptable to other consoles that will tolerate the frequencies and supply a max of 5.5V). it is powered via the gameboy's power supply and can output two clock signals which can be changed during gameplay, rather than only while the power is turned off. features:
  • two speeds:
    • normal speed (4.194304 MHz)
    • half speed (2.097152 MHz)
  • small size (7.5mm x 12.15mm x 1.75mm)
  • RoHS compliant
kit includes:
  • easy_CLK PCB
  • hook-up wires for power and clock output
  • wire jumper
installation documentation (powerpoint format):
  • english
  • español (pronto)
  • português (breve)
installation documentation (pdf format):
  • english
  • español (pronto)
  • português (breve)
the kit is shipped with a wire jumper so that you can solder it into the PCB and activate the circuit. it comes without a switch to save cost for you, but mainly to allow for more customization on your end. there are hundreds of switches that should work, you need a basic SPDT type. if you have questions about a particular switch, feel free to contact us before ordering.

name: quint
description:
quint is a *duino-core device meant as a 'clock' control mechanism for handheld gaming devices, notably the game boy original, color, and pocket consoles. it is capable of supplying independent frequencies to two devices through its 3.5mm jacks. features list:
  • 5 illuminated tactile switches, 1 non-illuminated
  • 1 illuminated sliding potentiometer
  • 1 micro-switch
  • powered externally via the game boys or USB header
  • optional USB connectivity with this device
  • ships with ADABOOT bootloader
  • fully compatible with Arduino IDE (atmega328 based)
  • available ICSP port (requires removal of micro-switch to reprogram)
  • hand-assembled with <3 and fully tested

name: 3.5mm (1/8") audio splitter
description:
this product splits a stereo signal into two identical stereo signals.  fits perfectly into the gameboy's 3.5mm (1/8") headphone or prosound output.

available in white or black plastic.

name: backlighting film
description:
these films are meant for the diy-er in their backlighting and optical experiments.

the polarization film is primarily meant to replace the film that is peeled off in the backlighting process.  our diffusion film is a custom product which helps diffuse the light and adds a reflective layer which brightens the backlight.  both are LCD quality.

the diffusion film has a notch cut in the corner to stay in place securely in a DMG.  

to change the polarization film between the normal and inverted look, simply rotate the film 90 degrees during installation.  they are perfectly square pieces of film, and can be turned easily.

each film has a protective plastic layer on each side, which needs to be removed before use.  

these films also fit in a gameboy pocket.  the films are easily cut with scissors or a razor.

name: tri-wing and cross screwdrivers
description:
used with video game consoles which use the tri-wing screw to hold the casing together, such as the nintendo® game boy®.

the cross screwdriver is a standard phillips-head, and completes the tools needed to take out all of a gameboy's screws.

name: clear plastic circuit cases
description:
These are empty plastic cases, which hold the circuit board of your Game Boy® games.  The screw is a + type (phillips), so its easy to open.

Swap out your cases on your Nintendo® games, or use these with your non-USB Bleepbloop carts!

name: single custom buttons
description:
these are extra parts from the manufacturing of the hand-cast and machine-cast custom buttons. keycode:
  • dmg - dot matrix game boy (the original/classic)
  • mgb - game boy pocket
  • cgb - game boy color
  • nes - nintendo entertainment system
  • dpad - directional pad
  • power - power switch
each item is a single button.

options.name: mgb A or B - clear red

name: clearance
description:
these are random items which for various reasons need to go! they're priced to move quickly, if you see something better grab it soon. its all in limited quantity, put here to clear up space in the shop for other things. everything on this page is sold as-is. if any of the items need further explanation, descriptions will follow:
    SID chips
    • all of these chips have some sort of error with either a voice or a filter, in most the low-pass doesn't work correctly
    • these are NOS
    • these ICs came from a bulk purchase of hundreds of SIDs, these are the (relatively few) which didn't pass all the audio tests
    • the marking on the IC seen in the picture is paint, I mark them during the testing process to keep track of the ones i've checked
    white Nintendo Power flash cartridges
    • these are pre-flashed with LSDJ ver. 4.0.2
    • proof of LSDJ ROM purchase required to buy these (check out the FAQ for info on LSDJ verification)
    everdrive-GG
    • very lightly used
    • version 1.0 (non-USB)
    master everdrive
    • very lightly used
    • version 1.1 (non-USB)
    custom dmg cases
    • all have some cosmetic blemishes so they couldn't be sold as normal
    • they are otherwise fine

name: utilities
description:
these items are the 'extra' sorts of things which are needed to make some transactions work.  things like shipping, or individualized items, or just ways to deal with non-traditional exchanges.

you'll probably know if you need to buy any of this stuff ;)

name: 3.5mm stereo audio splitter (y-cable)
description:
this item will split a single stereo audio signal into two stereo signals.

the cable is ~17cm (6.5") long and white.  one end has a male plug, the other end has two independent female jacks.  all are 3.5mm (1/8") stereo.

the contacts are gold-plated.

name: backlit GBA LCD screen
description:
this is a replacement LCD screen for the GameBoy Advance console with a built-in backlight. these are newly manufactured parts. kit includes:
  • replacement LCD screen
  • adapter ribbon cable for easy installation
  • hook-up wire
kits come in two options depending on the style connector needed to fit your GBA: 32-pin or 40-pin. information on identifying which kit is required can be found in the documentation and also in the last product photo on this page. installation tutorial and documentation coming soon! (buyers, i'll email you the temporary install docs)

name: arduinoboy (thursday customs)
description:
a thursday customs production! thursday customs is always working towards improving their products. with the redesign of their NES-style Arduinoboy they are using higher quality components and have given it a minimalistic new look. at first glance the "invisible" LEDs, flush MIDI sockets and link port cover make this arduinoboy look just like a standard NES controller. the mode switch is now both "A"+"B" buttons, making sure you never accidentally switch modes at the wrong time. all the features from the original arduinoboy project remain intact. Features:
  • MIDI in/out
  • powered via DMG link cable
  • "invisible" white status/mode LEDs
  • all buttons maintain original tactile feeling
  • 'A' + 'B' buttons act as mode switch(press both at the same time)
  • link port for syncing additional Game Boy (DMG type)
  • 7 modes. in order:
    • LSDJ slave sync
    • LSDJ master sync
    • LSDJ keyboard
    • Nanoloop
    • MidiGB
    • LSDJ map
    • LSDJ MIDI out
additional information on Trash80's arduinoboy project may be found here.

name: hex DMG v1
description:
this is a simple break out board for a dual inverter IC.  it can be used to "bi-vert" your original game boy (dmg).  bi-version gives you a much sharper contrast for your backlit lcd.  it will however be more difficult to see in full daylight.

installation instructions are in the 4th picture.  make sure that your backlit lcd is inverted.

name: LEDx3
description:
these are LED backlights for the nintendo game boy DMG and pocket consoles.† the current version is variant c (vc). more colors may also be available here. this backlight features:
  • 3 LEDs for uniform light distribution (bottom-illuminated)
  • 1.4mm thickness
  • installs to a regulated power source
  • resistors specific to the LED color
  • available in either normal or inverted polarization
  • reinforced hookup wire solder joints
  • built-in resistors
  • built-in polarization film
  • RoHS compliant
  • installation documentation:††
    • english (pdf, ppt)
    • español (pdf, ppt)
IMPORTANT! all backlight variations install slightly different than other kits that are available and from each other. please read the documentation before your order, and especially before doing your installation ;) † off-site tutorials for installing LEDx3 in a gameboy pocket are available. VG console modder arfink did a tutorial illustrating how this is done with a 'variant A' (va) backlight. be warned, the pocket's LCD screen is very fragile, more so than that of the DMG. keep this in mind when removing the polarization film. also, the pocket's LCD reacts oppositely to the polarization film you order. if you want your screen to look 'normal' you will need inverted film. for the screen to look 'inverted' please order a kit with normal film. †† this documentation is made for (vb). the (vc) kit is the same as the (vb) kit, apart from an updated LED PCB within the backlight. the wires coming from the backlight are in a reversed order than those of (vb). this doesn't affect which color wire is soldered during installation, it only mean you no longer need to cross the wires during installation, making it cleaner to install. follow the instructions for the (vb) kit, paying attention to the color of the wire you are soldering. when in doubt, the black wire is ground, the colored wire is 5V.

name: everdrive-64
description:
this item is a flash cartridge for the n64 console, developed by krikzz. all available software and updates may be found on his site. this cartridge features:
  • support for 99% of known n64 games
  • 64Mbyte (512mbit) SDRAM for ROM data
  • SD and SDHC cards are supported
  • FAT16/FAT32 support. unlimited partition size for fat32
  • SD to SDRAM transfer speed up to 14Mbyte/s
  • emulation features
  • gamepack saves support (SRAM, SRAM128Kbyte, EEPROM16k, EEPROM4k, FlashRam)
  • region free. can play PAL ROM on NTSC system and vice-versa
  • cic boot emulator. enough to have cic-6102/7101 for playing all games
  • cart does not need any extra software for PC
  • byteswoped and non byteswoped ROMs are supported
  • USB port 800k - 1Mbyte/s (optional)
  • firmware update through SD card
  • runs on all n64 consoles (any revisions and region)
  • 6105 boot chip support
important: this cart requires a CIC chip to operate, so please be sure to purchase your cartridge with this chip already installed, or supply one yourself from an original n64 cartridge. CIC-6102 is for NTSC systems and CIC-7101 for PAL systems.

name: everdrive-md
description:
this is a flash cartridge for the sega genesis/megadrive console with a sd/mmc interface designed by krikzz. it features:
  • all SEGA megadrive/genesis games supported, except virtua racing
  • most SEGA maser system games supported
  • 32x games supported
  • SEGA-CD bios loading
  • hardware megakey
  • save ram data can be stored or loaded from SD card
  • saves available for megadrive/genesis and master system games
  • SD/MMC cards up to 32GB
  • FAT16/FAT32 support
  • flashed game will stay in memory after power off. there is no need to choose and reflash game after each reset or power off
  • connection to PC and any additional software/drivers is not required
  • GameGenie codes are supported
flash cartridge comes with the pcb only. you will need to supply an empty case, as well as the sd/mmc card you wish to use. the only modification required to fit this in a case is trimming away a space for the sd card and the tact switch.

name: mega-everdrive
description:
this is a flash cartridge for the SEGA megadrive (genesis) console with a SD card and USB interface. it is designed by krikzz, all software and updates may be found on his website. this cartridge features:
  • 128mbit (16mbyte) SDRAM
  • 80mbit (10mbyte) max ROM size
  • firmware updates through SD card
  • standard SD and micro SD card slots
  • FAT / FAT16 / FAT32 support
  • SD cards up to 32GB
  • near-instant loading (1-2 sec)
  • USB port for homebrew development and for future features
  • in-game menu that allows access back to the menu system
  • snapshot saves
  • regular game battery back-up saves
  • genesis, mega-drive, sega master system, and 32X games supported
  • hardware MEGAKEY
  • CD BIOS loading
  • CD RAM cart feature
  • cheats feature; Game Genie and Play-Action Replay format supported
  • built in audio playback; currently only WAV is supported, but some other formats may be supported in the future

name: turbo-everdrive
description:
this is a flash cartridge for PCE/TG16 consoles, with a micro-SD interface. this device is designed by krikzz, software updates and support may be found through his website. this cartridge features:
  • PC-Engine and TurboGrafx-16 systems are supported
  • FAT / FAT16 / FAT32 file formats are supported
  • supports micro-SD cards up to 32GB
  • quick loading, approx. 5 - 10 seconds
  • USB port for homebrew development (optional)
  • Street Fighter II mapper support
  • on-board reset button
  • 8Mbyte of ROM memory
important information:
  • cart may not work properly with region modded systems
  • USB version of cart will not fit in SuperGrafx

name: super-everdrive
description:
this flash cartridge is for the snes console and features a sd/mmc interface, dsp1 socket, and optional usb port. it was developed by krikzz, and more information can be found on his website (including the current and available software). the cartridge features:
  • 32Kb FRAM for game saves (no battery required)
  • save RAM data can be stored and loaded from the SD card
  • game ROM can be loaded from the SD card
  • max supported ROM size is 48Mbit (6Mbyte)
  • SD/MMC cards supported
  • FAT16 support - 2GB max partition size
  • supports both PAL and NTSC systems
  • USB port for developers (optional)

name: master everdrive
description:
this is a sd/mmc capable flashcart for the sega master system by krikzz. features:
  • max supported ROM size of 8mbit (1mbyte)
  • 32kb FRAM for game saves
  • support for SMS and SG-1000 games
  • support for standard sega mapper and codemasters mapper
  • cartridge can be used on the sega game gear using a game gear adapter
  • operating system can be updated via the SD port
  • RAM data can be loaded or saved from the SD card
  • support for both SD and MMC cards
  • SD/MMC cards are limited to a 2GB partition, with FAT16 formatting
  • the FRAM will store game saves even after power-off. there is also no need for a battery for game saves
addition support may be found on krikzz' site here.

name: backlit and prosound DMG (thursday customs)
description:
a Thursday Customs production! the original grey Game Boy with added backlight for anytime visibility and prosound output for recording and playing live music. this item features:
  • great condition, gently used
  • new screen cover
  • new battery contacts
  • battery cover and link port cover included
  • DMG-CPU-04 and up (no wav channel glitches)
  • choose backlight color/prosound in the drop down menu

name: variable clock v4
description:
this is a variable clock output device using the popular LTC1799 IC. you can manipulate the Game Boy's processor 'clock' frequency on the fly with a potentiometer for variable speeds. this is perfect for gamers that want a fast paced game to be easier (or harder) or to be be able to speed through those slow RPG games! the pitch of the sound will become lower when slowed down and it will become higher when sped up. additionally, processor clock dependent features such as tempo will be affected. you can make some incredible sounds and noises with this kit! built-in features:
  • on/off push button switch:
    • no need to solder a separate switch. this kit has it built right in.
  • main pot:
    • no need to solder a separate potentiometer for controlling this kit. it's built right in. the knob is also included.
  • low limiter:
    • with the 500K "main pot" this kit will go so slow and low that the notes will sound like a droning "growl"
    • this kit comes with a 500K trim pot pre-installed. this will allow you to set the low limit before you install it or you can install it at the top of an Original Game Boy (DMG) and the low limiter can be accessed through a small hole with a screw driver so that it can be adjusted on the fly.
    • check out this video for a demonstration of how this feature works
installation instructions:
  • please refer to picture 2 for hook-up information
  • installation into the case will require drilling the appropriate holes

name: RGBss
description:
a collaborative project with thursday customs, this is a kit which adds RGB LED illumination and color-control ability to the start/select buttons of the game boy original console. features:
  • 0.6mm thickness
  • two RGB LEDs
  • solder points for use with RGBbb backlight
  • solder points for independent RGB control
  • easy to install
  • hand-assembled with <3 and fully tested
kit includes:
  • clear silicon start/select button
  • RGBss circuit board
documentation (coming soon):
  • powerpoint:
  • pdf:

name: 3_clk
description:
coming soon! this kit outputs frequencies of 2 MHz, 4 MHz and 8 MHz. it is designed for use with the original game boy console as a replacement for its crystal oscillator. this kit provides approximate half, normal, and double speed frequencies to your console. because the original gameboy's CPU clocks at 4.194304 MHz, running at 4 MHz results in an out-of-tune audio response (the notes will be 'flat'). this tutorial by little-scale illustrates a method whereby LSDJ can be 'retuned' so this kit will then provide a true half, normal, and double speed audio response. documentation:
  • installation guide: english (coming soon)

name: cartridge case
description: a case to hold nintendo® game boy® games.  available in red, yellow, green, or purple.  snap-shut.

name: high quality tri-wing screwdriver
description:
high-quality tri-wing screwdriver.  great for opening up gameboys with tri-wing screws.

this screwdriver is longer than the red types we sell.  the butt-end of the screwdriver rotates separately from the handle, making turning this screwdriver much easier than the cheaper red ones.

name: nanoloop 2.x
description:
nanoloop is a step-sequencer which means that a pattern of 16 1/16 notes is played repeatedly while these notes can be edited in various respects like volume, pitch, etc. there are four channels, which play simultaneously. each channel's patterns can be saved to file slots in flash memory and are then available for new combinations. finally, saved patterns can be arranged in a song structure. nanoloop is in game cartridge format, as pictured. purchase includes:
  • nanoloop cartridge
  • official manual
  • usb adapter (more info)
series 2 of nanoloop is compatible with the nintendo GBA and GBA SP consoles. you may read more about this particular version of nanoloop on its hompage found here. price reflects the cost of the cartridge from the nanoloop website, converted into USD, at the time of our purchase.

name: arduinoboy #2 (thursday customs)
description:
a thursday customs production! this item features:
  • original light grey DMG shell
  • MIDI in/out
  • white backlight & power LED
  • 1/8" (3.5mm) prosound
  • dark grey buttons and screen cover
  • dmg-cpu-06
  • tested, working 100%
additional information on Trash80's arduinoboy project may be found here.

name: security bits
description:
3.8mm security bits are used to open up nes, snes, n64, game boy original and color games that use these special security bit screws.  

4.5mm security bits are used to open nes, snes, n64, gamecube, game gear, turbo grafx, etc. and all systems that use these special security bits screws.

made of quality metal, unlike many of these bits found elsewhere.  will not strip easily.  fits into a standard drill for power tool operation, if so desired.

brand new, never used.  price is for one bit.  please choose which size you need before adding to the cart.

name: GB Boy Colour
description:
these are clones of the gameboy color console, called the GB Boy Colour.

they are designed to work with the gameboy-style cartridges, but since these are not made, nor endorsed, by Nintendo full compatibility cannot be assured.

the color LCD is backlit.

name: game case
description:
this is a padded, protective carrying case for handheld consoles.  fits consoles DMG-sized and smaller.

cardboard packaging may be removed depending on how we ship your order.

name: stereo amplifier for cgb
description:
this is a plug-in stereo amplifier for the gameboy color system.  

requires 2 aaa batteries.

color is a frosted translucent purple.

name: replacement cgb case kit
description:
this is a replacement case kit for your gameboy color. kit includes:
  • replacement housing
  • silicon pads
  • buttons
  • screen cover
  • tri-wing screwdriver
this case is not designed to the exact specifications as the original nintendo housing, so the original buttons (and our cgb buttons) will not properly fit. however, the included buttons with this kit work fine.

name: drag'n'derp cartridge
description:
a professor abrasive product! this is a flash cartridge for the game boy console. the cartridge features:
  • game boy original/color cartridge style
  • driverless, drag-and-drop operation
  • FRAM (no back-up battery required)
  • ROM: 24mbit/3mbyte
  • RAM: 1mbit/128kbyte
  • USB 2.0 full speed
  • micro-USB connector
  • works with: winXP, win7, OS X (10.5/10.6), linux 3.4.4
instructions for use:
  • plug into the computer with a micro-USB cable
  • wait for the cart to appear as a new USB drive
  • to back up, drag the save contents and/or ROM off the drive
  • to program, drop new save and/or ROM files on to the drive
  • that's it, you can unplug and use the cart!
to upgrade your firmware, please visit here. cartridge does not include clear case. current batch has a translucent black shell.

name: rca to 3.5mm (1/8") stereo cable
description:
this cable is used to connect a 3.5mm jack to a rca device, or vice versa.  3.5mm jacks and rca jacks are all male on this cable.

cable is black, and 30cm (~12 inches) long.

name: clear cartridge case
description:
these are clear, nintendo-manufactured, cases for your gameboy cartridges.

it is used but in good condition.
